text:
ANNETTE CRUZ: We would like
to take this opportunity to officially welcome you
to today's session Emerging

Trends in Building
Decarbonization with Peter Rumsey. Peter Rumsey, founder of
Point Energy Innovations,

stands at the forefront of low
energy and net zero building innovation with over 40 years
of distinguished experience.

Based in San Francisco,
his engineering expertise has contributed to 50 LEED
platinum projects, the highest

number by any
engineer in the US. Renowned nationally
and globally, he

collaborates with
top tech firms, educational institutions,
and developers. Celebrated for his
pioneering contributions,

Peter has garnered accolades,
such as the renewable energy innovator of the year
and ASHRAE's Award

of Engineering Excellence. A Stanford lecturer
for over a decade, he's also the visionary
behind the Stanford building

Decarbonization
Learning Accelerator, which equips academics with
leading decarbonization

insights and materials. Now I'll turn it
over to you, Peter. PETER RUMSEY: Great, thank
you, Annette, looking forward

to today's session. I'm going to go through some
of the concepts on building

decarbonization. And we'll welcome your
questions at the end. You can put them
into the Q&A window.

And then we'll go through those. So the thing about building
decarbonization-- we all

know why it's imperative that
we start focusing on this.

We're seeing a lot of
evidence of climate change. Some of it's dramatic. But I think some of the other
reasons why decarbonization

matters is that air
quality is impacted heavily by the use of fossil fuels.

Particles, NOx, SOx, all
these different things

are part of air
pollution that's caused by the use of fossil fuels.

The other thing to understand
is that fossil fuels do disproportionately
impact people of color.

Black people in the
US are 10 times-- children are 10 times
more likely to get asthma

than white children. Most of that has to do with
fenceline communities living

near fossil fuel processing
and extraction facilities.

I think that the other thing
that's really interesting is that the cost of
our gas infrastructure

is increasing rapidly. Right now, the spending
on maintaining the gas

infrastructure has gone up
by 300% in the last 10 years plus or minus.

And that's just only going
to increase over time. Most of the gas infrastructure
in the US is over 50 years old.

Much of it's 100 years old. And it's going to
cost a lot of money to keep that gas
infrastructure going.

So there's a lot of
reasons that we should be talking about decarbonization.

And I imagine many of you are
part of the building industry. And we do play an
important role.

Buildings do account
for roughly 40% of the greenhouse gas
emissions globally.

And the number in the
US is also very similar. Within that, there's
both the operational side

and the construction side. And we'll talk about those. I think the thing
that's exciting

and a challenge for
all of us is there's a lot of legislation
that's now being passed

and a lot of activity
that's changing how we think about buildings. New York City, for example,
now has their Local Law 97

for buildings over
25,000 square feet. They have to meet energy
efficiency and greenhouse gas

emissions limits. And some of those are
going to be somewhat strict

when we get to 2030. And in California, there's a
wide variety of legislation

that is getting
passed around this. I think one of the
more important ones is the SB 100 that is saying,
by 2045, the electricity--

100% of electricity needs to
be carbon free in California. I think it's also
interesting in Texas that--

that's a state with
the largest amount of renewable energy in
the US at 59 gigawatts

and growing rapidly. And there's a variety
of legislation happening in Texas as well.

Oh, sorry. There's also a variety of
different things going on

at the federal level. But I think the
most significant is this Inflation
Reduction Act, the IRA,

and its impact on buildings
as well as energy production.

There are literally
billions of dollars available now for clean energy.

But there's also a
lot of money that's going to be available
for buildings. Much of that is in
the residential sector

for building energy
efficiency and heat pumps. But there's a wide--

a large amount of
that money will also be impacting the commercial
and industrial sector.

Another interesting
act that was passed

that we don't hear about as much
is the Defense Production Act, where $500 million
has been put aside

to fund domestic
manufacturing of heat pumps and other critical minerals.

And I think that that's going to
change the availability of heat pumps very rapidly.

And we'll be talking a little
bit about heat pumps today. So when we break down carbon
emissions from buildings,

there's two areas. One is embodied carbon. And we did have a seminar
on that a couple of weeks

ago, where we dove
into embodied carbon and how to decarbonize the
construction of buildings.

The other side and the larger
side is the operational carbon. And that is the carbon
emissions that's

associated with using
energy in buildings. And there's two ways that
we use energy in buildings.

One would be that we burn
natural gas at the building, primarily for heating--
different heating needs--

space heating, water
heating, laundry. But there's also cooking.

So we're going to dive into
operational carbon today. But before we do that, I did
want to just remind everybody,

for those of you who didn't
get to attend the last seminar, is that the path for
embodied decarbonization,

that is, the embodied
carbon, is fairly clear.

We can start by reusing
existing buildings and doing renovations instead
of building new and remembering

that embodied carbon is
dominated by steel and concrete or cement more directly.

So reusing buildings is a really
good thing where possible. In the US, that's a
very doable thing.

The next step is choosing
carbon sequestering materials where available.

Wood is one of those
that sequesters CO2 into the wood that will
go into the building.

And now there's this
whole emerging area of mass timber buildings. And we've worked on
a variety of those.

And it seems to be
growing rapidly. And then there's the
option of specifying

low-carbon materials. And a variety of
manufacturers of everything

from cement to steel are now
offering low carbon materials. There's even a steel
company in the US

that's now offering what they
say is a carbon free steel. And that is steel that's
made with electricity

that's generated from
renewable sources. And then last but not least, for
the remaining embodied carbon

that we can't get
down to zero, we can do different types of
high quality carbon offsets

to do that. And I'll give an example of a
project where that was done.

On the operational side,
operational decarbonization,

the path is also clear,
if anything more clear. If we take a typical building
and start by making it

more energy efficient,
that's the first and I would argue the
most important step.

And we will talk about
energy efficiency today. And then making that efficient
building all electric

and finding electric
ways to generate heat as a primary thing-- and
I'll talk about that.

And then last but
not least is power that efficient all electric
building with renewable energy.

And that can be either
on site or off site. So I'll give some
examples of that.

In this quick time
that we have together, I just wanted to share with you
some of the energy efficiency

blockbusters that have already
made their way into the market.

LED lighting is by far
the most well known. Some estimates
have that reducing

the need for several hundred
power plants globally. The introduction of
LED lighting that

has been super significant. It permeates all
different building types.

But there's also the
variable air volume box, which is a quiet but an
unsung hero in the HVAC

world and commercial buildings. Before we had
constant volume boxes, now we have variable volume
boxes for delivering air.

That's something that is reduced
heating and cooling energy

in commercial buildings by-- the heating and cooling
energy by at least 50%.

There's low emissivity glazing,
which is also a significant--

reducing building
envelope loads. And I would argue that
the variable speed

drive is potentially
globally equally as important as LED lighting. And not a lot of
people know about that.

But variable speed drives impact
buildings but also factories

and a variety of
other industrial uses. So there are several
and there are

other examples of blockbusters
in the energy efficiency side.

So if we look at
the ASHRAE standard 90.1 for building
energy efficiency, which

is a recommended
standard, many states do use it as their
building energy code.

When we started with that
standard in the mid 1970s-- and we pegged that at an
energy use of relative of 100.

And we look at the different
versions of ASHRAE 90.1 over the years to
where we are today.

And there's actually a new
version that just came out. We're seeing over 50% reduction
in energy consumption.

And this ASHRAE 90.1 is
not that hard to meet

with off-the-shelf
technologies today. I mean, most
commercial buildings

do come very close
to meeting it. And it doesn't take a lot of
effort to get over the line.

So this is super significant. Not a lot of people understand
that from the '70s to where

we are today, buildings are
using half as much energy per square foot.

It's a very big deal. What are the next generation of
energy efficiency blockbusters?

There are several. But my feeling is that
heat pumps are really very

much at the top of the list. Using AI for energy
optimization in buildings

is something that
I think we're going to see a lot of over
the next 10 or 20 years. I think building
control systems,

be they small or large, are very
much dumb building controls.

Or let's call them
smart time clocks. But we could do so
much more in buildings to optimize the energy use.

Induction cooking is
going to be very large. I'll talk about
that for a minute.

Integrative design,
where we think more holistically about the
design of energy efficiency

in buildings, that's going
to be very important. And it is something
that is growing.

Personal comfort in
buildings-- the number one complaint of occupants
in commercial buildings

is too hot, too cold. And I think that
we could do a lot for improving individual
comfort in buildings.

And that's where we
really need to get to provide higher
level of comfort because everybody wants
something a little bit

different. And there are examples of
that that are now emerging. And it's somewhat
connected to using AI.

And then low pressure
drop systems-- one of the things that's
near and dear to my heart. And I will mention that briefly.

So if we put together all
of the energy efficiency

that is state-- what I like to call state of the
shelf easily available but not

commonly used-- if we start with the
baseline building-- and this would be one that
meets the ASHRAE 90.1 standard--

and put together a more energy
efficient building envelope, better lighting,
better daylighting--

that's part of that-- improved plug load, meaning
things that we plug in-- better

computers, better monitors-- and low friction systems,
meaning lower pressure

drop ducts and pumps, and
then put in a heat pump, we can get the
energy consumption

of a building down relatively
easily by 40% plus or minus.

And this building
that we modeled-- and we've done it in a
wide variety of climates.

So this particular one
was in North Carolina. And that building-- then
we put on 40% of the roof.

It was a three- or
four-story building. 40% of the roof, we
covered with photovoltaics. And it brought the
energy use down further

and that significant
chunk of the energy needs of the building. And then we covered the
building with 80% of the roof

with photovoltaics. And that on an
annual basis covered all of the energy consumption.

And then I think
the thing that we're going to start seeing are
batteries used in buildings.

I think that batteries are
going to be another blockbuster that we're going to see
widely deployed in buildings.

So energy efficiency
has a huge potential. We move on to building
electrification.

Remember, I said that the
steps for the decarbonization are make the building
efficient first. And then we electrify
the building.

The main tool that
we're going to have in electrifying
buildings is heat pumps.

And the beauty of heat pumps is
that, for a gas heating system, we need to put in something
like 105 or 110 units of gas

to get 100 units of heat out. That's a good 90%
efficient boiler.

But for a heat pump, we can
put 33 units of electricity in to get 100 units
of heating out.

And that's because
heat pumps are able to pull heat from outside
air and change the temperature

and deliver that as heat. And the waste product of
heat pumps for some buildings is actually beneficial.

That is it's cooling. And so you can imagine a
building where in the summer

we're trying to make
hot water for things like showers or laundry.

And our waste
products is cooling. So we're working on
buildings where-- and Stanford's
central plan actually

has a system where when
they need cooling-- when they need heating,
they capture the cooling

and use that and vice versa. When they need cooling,
they capture the heat and use that if there's
a simultaneous use.

So heat pumps are
very efficient and can provide a lot of benefits that
gas boilers can't provide.

So the forecast
for heat pumps are

that there's going to be a very
rapid growth in the use of heat pumps. This is already happening.

It's happening very
rapidly right now in Europe because of
their transition away

from natural gas
for obvious reasons. But we're seeing a similar pick
up in the use of heat pumps

in the US. And heat pumps
are not brand new. They've been around
for quite some time.

Combined heat pump air
conditioner for residential use has been around for decades now.

And I've seen that on
houses all over the US. It's widely used. And that is a nice
thing is that you can get one piece of equipment
that can provide both heating

and cooling. So heat pumps are going to be a
significant part of our future.

When we're talking about
electrifying cooking-- gas cooking, we are all
very familiar with that.

And electric resistance cooking
has been around for decades.

Most people don't like
electric resistance cooking for a wide variety of reasons.

But electric induction
cooking is where what we're going to see when we start
moving to electric cooking.

And electric induction
uses a magnetic field instead of heating a coil. And the magnetic field heats the
pot only and not the surface.

And it's very rapid. It boils water faster
than most gas stoves. And then it's also very
precise in going up and down.

So electric induction
is going to catch on. And we're seeing that
starting to happen.

One of the things about gas
cooking that's coming out now is that the indoor air
pollution from gas cooking

is significant. A recent study by Stanford, in
addition to other indoor air

pollutants that are caused
by using natural gas, they found that benzene
concentration of gas stoves

is pretty bad in kitchens. And and this is--
it actually just came out earlier this year.

It was a fairly
significant finding. They did a wide variety
of tests on that.
So it's interesting. As we start to electrify homes--

and this is sort of
looking into the future. Part of what we're
doing at Stanford

is trying to see how these
things are going to go. We are anticipating some
homes will become electrified.

And others will
still be using gas. And, really, the
worst case scenario is if a house is electrified
and the last thing you have

is a gas stove. So we have to maintain
the gas infrastructure, the utility does, for
very small use of gas.

And what will happen
is gas will start to become very expensive because
the infrastructure is the same.

But the use has gone down. And so there is this idea
of targeted electrification.

If we can get a
whole neighborhood-- and this is where utilities
would target programs--

a whole neighborhood
to electrify, then, in that
neighborhood, they can abandon the gas infrastructure
and save all the money

of maintaining that system. So this is looking
into the future. This is not something
that's happening next year.

But if you play this out
over the next few decades, this is the kind
of thing that we'll need to start thinking about.

Simultaneously, the cost of
renewables and the adoption of renewables,
especially photovoltaics,

have been just accelerating. And you might or
might not be aware.

But in the US, over
the last few years, of the new generation capacity
that was added in the US,

75%, 80% of that was
renewables-- solar and wind. And solar is the bulk of that.

Similarly, battery
storage is globally is growing very rapidly
and anticipated

to continue to do so, batteries
being a really important part of having a high percentage
of solar on the grid.

And we're going to see
batteries at the utility scale as well as at buildings.

And utility rates
are going to start to change to be time
of use types of rates

so that the cost is
higher during the periods

when the sun is not available. And so batteries
are going to become more and more economical. In several states,
those kind of rates

have already been implemented. And they're making batteries
very cost effective.

So another thing to be aware of
on this move towards renewables

is 22 states have already put
in place commitments, usually

laws at the state level
saying that the grid needs to be 100% carbon free
by 2050 or sooner.

As I mentioned,
California has a 2045. So there's a lot going on.

And I just wanted to share with
you a couple different examples of these types of buildings.

The RMI Innovation Center is
one that's in basalt Colorado. So it's a cold climate,
gets very cold in

the winter, lots of snow. But it's also sunny. And so they-- RMI spent some time thinking
about this building.

How can they make it a
super efficient building? And RMI is a
nonprofit organization

that works in the space
of decarbonization, have been doing
that for many years.

And so they started
thinking, OK, we're going to put in
really good windows.

And these are super
windows that have very high insulating qualities.

They're going to get a lot
of daylight into the space. You can see it here. And they even have-- this is
a south side of the building.

They've set up the building so
that, when the sun comes in, it hits the floor and heats up
the floor in the winter months

but does not shine
directly on the desk. So they don't have the desks
right up at the window. So they get the daylight.

They get the passive solar gain. And they get a highly insulated
building at the same time.

They even have chairs that
provide individual comfort through heating and cooling--

heating and then fan
ventilation on the chairs so that people can get to
the comfort that they want.

The interesting
thing about that-- and they also insulated
the building envelope, the non-glass parts of
the envelope very highly--

is that it allowed them
to eliminate the expense. They were going to put in--

initially, the idea was to put
in a big ground source heat pump system-- heat pump, all electric.

Nice system but very expensive. But instead of
buying the system-- the expense of
ground source system,

they put more and more money
into the building envelope. So they got to the point
that that wasn't needed.

And so all they needed
was a heat recovery ventilator and equivalent of six
hairdryers of electric heating.

So they put some small
electric baseboards into 15,000 square
foot building. So that's a very
small amount of heat.

So it's not a heat pump. But it was so little of
it that it made sense.

So this is integrative design. Overall, the building costs less
than what it would have cost

if they put in the heat pump. So another project that
I'm working on currently--

And. It's under construction--
is the American Institute of Architects Headquarters
in Washington, DC.

And this is a few blocks
away from the White House. It's a building that
was built in the '70s.

And at that time, building
insulation and good quality

windows was not a thing. And also, heating
and cooling systems were not done in a way
that's very energy efficient.

So what they're going
to do is they're going to replace the lighting,
put in LED lighting instead

of inefficient older fluorescent
lighting, and better lighting fixtures.

And they're going to
set the building up for better daylighting. And instead of
really dark glass, they're going to put
in a lighter glass that

transmits more of the daylight. They are going to
put in new glazing-- double glazing low
emissivity glazing

that lets the light in
but blocks the heat out in the summer months. And they are going to
electrify the building.

So they're going to
take the natural gas boilers that make steam. And they're going to
abandon those, take them out

of the building. And then they're going to
put heat pumps on the roof to make the hot water.

And it's interesting
because, with the reduction of the load from the
electric from the lighting

system and the oversizing
of the building, even though they're adding
all this new electric load

and the heat pumps,
they don't need to upsize the electric
service to the building.

So they are going to put
some solar photovoltaics on the roof. This is a seven-story building.

And that's only going
to amount to about 10% of the annual use
of the building.

So what they're
going to do is they are going to purchase offsite
renewably generated electricity

through this Pepco DC
Power Connect program. And with the Power
Connect program,

you can select your
generation provider. And there's a few options
for generation providers

that have 100% renewable. It's a combination
of wind and solar. And the one that they're using
is called Clean Choice Energy.

And so they will be
purchasing-- at least the part of their bill that
goes to generation

will be going to
renewable energy. So they have
onsite, 10% offsite,

90% renewable electricity for
now an all electric building.

Interesting thing is
about the embodied carbon of this building--
reusing the building.

Instead of building
a new building,

it's saving 76% of
the embodied carbon. So they're just avoiding
that embodied carbon

by reusing building. So you can see that's
the biggest step. But the next step
that they're taking

to offset the remaining
embodied carbon-- and it has a lot to do with the
windows that they're purchasing,

furniture, carpet,
all the stuff that's going inside the building. And there is some steel
structural upgrades and things

like that. So what they're doing
for that is they have purchased solar panels.

And those have been
donated to Habitat for Humanity, who's
going to be installing

those solar panels on low-income
homes in DC and Northern Virginia. And those panels are going to
avoid electricity consumption

from the average
grid that does have coal and natural gas in it.

And that will
avoid carbon that's equivalent to the number of
panels that they bought--

is going to avoid carbon
from electricity that's equivalent to the embodied
carbon of the new materials

that they're
bringing to the site. So I think that's
a very creative way of doing an offset.

Obviously you don't have to do
it in such a deliberate way.

There's offsets
that you can buy, where people are
grouping them together. And it's important to
get high quality offsets.

I'd say that this
kind of offset is as high quality as you can get. I've worked a lot with a
company in India called Infosys.

And they are collaborators
with Stanford. And they have
30,000,000 square feet

of offices throughout the
country and 250,000 employees. So it's quite a large
footprint as far as buildings.

And they embarked about
10 years ago on a program

to make much more
efficient buildings and then to go back to
their existing buildings

and retrofit them. Overall, over that
period, they've reduced their electricity
consumption per employee

by 55%. I think it's probably the
largest corporate energy

efficiency program
that's ever happened. And I think it's
important to note that large energy
efficiency improvements are

possible in buildings. And one of my colleagues
at Stanford, Jim Sweeney,

did write a book. And it was based on research he
did with his graduate students

and postdocs over
a five-year period. They looked at
energy consumption

in the US, all
sectors, and said, based on the efficiency
that was available

at the time in the
earlier periods, in the '70s, when the oil crisis
happened, and then compare

that to where we are today. So how much fuel is consumed on
an airplane per passenger mile

over time? What about industrial
production? How much embodied
energy is in a car?

Or they looked at buildings. So they looked at a wide
variety of sectors in the US.

And what they found was energy
efficiency over the period from mid '70s until 2015
had provided more energy

reduction than all of
the new energy sources, domestic ones combined.

And they were looking at
nuclear power, renewables. All these things were
small compared to the gains

going to happen with
energy efficiency. So I'm going to wrap up now so
we can have some discussion.

The key takeaways from this
is that decarbonization is emerging rapidly for most
clients in most markets.

And I'd say some of it's being
driven by legislation and such.

But some of it's
just being driven by what the clients want.

And then, ultimately,
energy efficiency makes economic sense. So there's a wide
variety of reasons

that people are moving
in this direction. Heat pumps are rapidly evolving
as the demand for them surges.

And as a person who works
in the design of buildings,

where for commercial systems,
three or four years ago, there was maybe
three viable options

in each category on commercial
building heat pumps. Now I'm seeing today that
number be closer to 10.

And I'm seeing a lot of people
are calling me and saying, look, we've got some
new stuff coming out.

And I think that number will
be more like 15 or, by 2030,

more like 20 plus
options in each category.

I think one of the
more telling things was when I was at the national
conference for building heat

and cooling systems,
the ASHRAE conference, one of the oldest boiler
companies in America--

and their display
had a huge display right at the center
of their booth

at that show with a heat pump. It's their first heat pump. So that was encouraging
and significant.

I think low-carbon building
materials are emerging quickly. Not only are commercial
providers there,

we're seeing a lot of
research at universities on things like low carbon
and zero carbon concrete

and carbon sequestering
concrete and cement primarily. And we're seeing a lot of
research going to that.

And we're also seeing
venture capital money going in that direction. Energy efficiency remains key
element of decarbonization.

And then most
carbon-free electricity will be generated off site. I do get this question
a lot is, do we

have to put solar panels
on every building? Is that how we're
going to get there? I think at the end of
the day, solar and wind--

the majority of it
will be generated off site at utility scale because
it's more affordable that way.

We are going to continue
to see a lot of solar go on buildings because,
at the end of the day,

we can generate
electricity on buildings-- on the roof of
buildings usually, in most areas in the US,
cheaper than buying it.

And so solar is
going to continue to be attractive on buildings. But I think the
majority of renewables

are going to be
generated off site. And that's how we're going
to be able to decarbonize the operation of buildings.

Thank you.  ANNETTE CRUZ: Thank
you, Peter, for such

an interesting and
insightful presentation. Now we're going to
move over to the Q&A.

So I encourage everyone
to submit their questions in the box on your
console labeled Q&A.

Now let's get into some
of these questions. The first one is from George.

Carbon offsets have been
justifiably criticized from obfuscation,
inadequacy, impermanence.

Any comments? PETER RUMSEY: Yeah. I totally agree. And that's why high
quality offsets are--

the high quality is the
important part of it. And I think what
people are saying

is we could plant some
trees as an offset. But what if those trees five
years later or 10 years later

get cut down? And then that offset is
not an offset and actually could become a liability if
that's composting and creating

methane. So I really would urge
you to spend some time if you are going to go in
the direction of offsets

for the embodied carbon
in building the bit that's unavoidable-- to really
spend some time finding out

what is the quality offset. And I've been to a
couple of conferences where there's a lot of
discussion about that.

Some are saying that
the only quality offset that they can really count
on is carbon removal.

And that's where carbon CO2
is taken out of the air. That is so energy intensive.

There are questions
about whether or not carbon removal is actually
a valid way to go.

So that's why when we're
working with the IEA. We said, let's do
something that we know is really going to
make a difference here.

And that's where the solar
panel solution came up. So we could have a whole
discussion about offsets

and how to go about that. But I do think there
is some validity to it.
But caution needs to be used. ANNETTE CRUZ: Thanks, Peter.

I'll move us over to the
next question from Aaron. I believe that on-site
renewables is more efficient,

has less impact on the grid. And there are incentives for
moving forward with this. But our capitalist society
is penalizing this approach.

More centralized
energy generation is growing at a faster pace. What is your opinion
on this topic? And do you think we should
provide stronger incentives

for more distributed generation? PETER RUMSEY: Yeah. Well, there is a debate about
on site versus off site.

There's a lot of advantages of
distributed energy generation. And what I'm saying is on site.

And it gives a
resilience to the grid. If there's constraints on
a grid, that is points.

And as we electrify
this, this is going to be a little bit of an issue. There are points in the
electrical grid that are

going to become pinch points. And a lot of people
are saying that one of the major barriers to
full adoption of renewables

is the power lines that are
going to need to be built. And we need to
build a lot of them to get power lines from where
we can generate if we do it

centrally to where cities are. And so that would
say distributed

is much better
because we don't need to build new power lines when
we have the distributed-- that

is solar on roofs of buildings. There are still a good
number of incentives.

But the thing that's
really a disincentive is the net metering that occurs.

So each state has a different
net metering solution. In California,
there was recently

a rollback of the net metering. So it's not as
positive for people

to have their own
on-site generation. There are certain
states where it's just--

they're, basically, net
metering is not even available

because, for a
variety of reasons, the utilities don't
want to see that. Now, I don't think
it's possible to stop

remote or on-site renewables
because once we combine-- even if net metering is really
bad, there's no place that's

banned the use of solar. So you can have
solar with battery and not feed electricity
back into the grid

and get a large percentage
of your electricity generated on site. You probably in most
locations will still

need some off-site electricity. So anyway, I am a
proponent of on-site solar.

But I do think that
the solution is going to be a hybrid of
on site and off site.

So I'd leave it at that. But, again, it is an
important discussion to have. And each state is
sort of coming up

with a different
set of solutions. ANNETTE CRUZ: Thanks, Peter.

So the next one--
what do you see as the greatest barrier to
building decarbonization

at this moment?  PETER RUMSEY: I like that
question because it's something

that I think about a lot. And I think that 5
or 10 years ago, we

could say that a lot of the
technology is not there. I think now the
technology is there.

I think cost is still a barrier,
as we're still figuring out how do we make this cost effective.

Once people start doing it-- Americans are really
good at figuring out how

to make stuff cost effective. And that's something that
the world envies about what

we do know is that
we really have this ingenuity
around figuring out

how to make things affordable. So I think we're
in that period now.

And I'm seeing lots
of solutions that are making
electrification and energy

efficiency very affordable. I think that the next
thing that's there

is people's understanding
of, is it possible?

Do we want to do this? Are there risks that
we don't understand? I'm consulting with
a large company.

And they have the money. And the leadership
at the company

is on board with using solar and
getting more energy efficiency

out of their buildings. But what we're seeing is that
the facilities managers are now becoming a barrier.

Now, they're not being mean
or dumb, nothing like that. But they're just saying, look,
if I spend the time and energy

to put solar on the
roof of this building or change out the lighting or
the chiller, I'll save energy.

That would be good. And the money's got the company. But I'm not-- I'm taking risk. If I put in a new heating or
cooling system, it could break.

It's like a new thing. And it could break. One guy said, well, if
I put solar on the roof

and there's a hurricane and
water leaks through the roof, then I could lose
my job for that.

But if he does the
solar, he's not going to get any additional job
security or bonus or anything.

There's not incentives for
the middle management people to do the right thing.

So I really do feel that
there's perceived risks. And people's approach to
this is an important barrier.

And there's actually a group at
Stanford Business School that's studying, what are
the incentives that

are needed at the leadership
level within companies to get companies to change
how they approach their carbon

footprint or their
energy consumption, these kind of things. And so I do feel that
it's more than technology.

It's more than cost. There's a human element here. And I think we should
all be thinking about,

how do we incentivize and
celebrate the people who

accomplish these things? And what we're recommending
to this company and I'm consulting with
is financial incentives

of the cost of an overall
project of putting in a new chiller or a
heat pump or solar--

a small fraction of that cost
can go to a financial incentive to the facilities
management person.

That would, in many
times, be the barrier that we need to overcome. ANNETTE CRUZ: Wow, yeah.
I mean, think incentive is huge. So how do we crack that nut?

So our next question here is
on one of our key takeaways

actually. Are there heat pump
varieties which can replace portable
window based AC units?

Can they be cheap enough to
be used by low income people? PETER RUMSEY: Yeah, there are
window unit heat pumps air

conditioners, combined units. And there's also
through the wall units

that they use in hotels,
lower cost hotels. Those are also available in
heat pump air conditioners.
So it's the same compressor. But it's in a reversing mode.

So it uses the compressor to
make cold air in the summer. And then that same compressor,
it's got a reversing valve.

It works to provide
heat in the winter time. So they are available.

They are more expensive than
a cooling only window unit. But it's not
anything like double.

It's like 20% or 30% higher. So, yes, that is available
even for affordable housing

and low income. ANNETTE CRUZ: Thank you. Moving on to the
next one from Anico.

Can we get some more information
from the Colorado renewable project that you mentioned?

PETER RUMSEY: Yeah. So RMI-- the RMI Innovation
Center-- you can Google it.

They've written several
reports about the building because they really do
want to celebrate it.

Their website is rmi.org. That's the name of
the organization, RMI.

And if you Google the RMI
Innovation Center building--

and it's in basalt Colorado,
which is right next to Aspen-- you'll find some
reports on that.

It should be fairly easy. If you're having
trouble, just contact me. And I'll help direct you.

ANNETTE CRUZ: Thanks, Peter. Next one, has
education and building decarbonization expanded
so that future building

systems have knowledgeable
designers, engineers, and architects? PETER RUMSEY: Yeah.

Our Stanford Building
Decarbonization Learning Accelerator is specifically
addressing that issue.

I think that the next generation
of architects, engineers, and construction managers need
to understand this information.

The thing that I've-- and
I've been teaching a class at Stanford on this
topic for 15 years now.

And my class size has doubled
in the last few years. The students now get it that,
hey, climate change is there.

They've known that for a while. And there's a lot of
things about distress around climate and everything.

But what students are
starting to realize is that there's a
variety of solutions. And they want to understand
what are those solutions.

So we are seeing a rapid growth
in interest in this area.

But it's still early. Several of the
universities that we're working with and providing
teaching materials--

and you can also
go to our website and look at the teaching
materials at bdla.stanford.edu.
Those teaching materials are--

some of the universities that
we're talking to are saying, well, we've got a program in
talking about building systems

or architecture or whatever. And we want to start
layering in decarbonization. The professors are saying, yeah,
I'm hearing that more and more.

What is that? Can you help me out? And so I think that the next
generation-- the courses

that are going to teach the
next generation are, in a sense, being built out right now. So that within-- my estimation
is that within the next five

years, we're going to see most
major AEC programs teaching

and talking about
decarbonization in one form or another.

ANNETTE CRUZ: Great. Your BDLA center is
doing great work. So thanks, Peter.

Next question, can
you expand more on the profile of
a mixed fuel house

versus an all electric house
from renewable energy sources?

PETER RUMSEY: Yeah. So mixed fuel houses are the
majority of houses in America.

That is where we've got both
gas and electric available.

And I think that the
decarbonization of existing houses is going to take-- it's a multi-decade project.

First, I think it makes a lot
of sense in new construction if we're building a housing
development or new construction

remodels. It's easy to say,
let's just do electric. And some cities
around the country are now starting to
implement building codes that

are saying that new
construction has to be electric. It's interesting because in
the Southeast of the US--

and that is Southern states-- the penetration of electric
heating is already very high.

The number somewhere in the 70s. 70% of homes are already
using electric heating

of one form or another. Some of it's
electric resistance. But a lot of it's
also heat pumps.

And same thing with
electric cooking. They have the older electric
resistance cooking, not as

good as induction. But induction will start to
take over that market as well.

So there's a large
part of the US where 100% electric homes
is already a reality,

like a high percentage of them. And so I think when
we're talking about this, we need to remember it's
not like a weird, new thing.

This is something that's
been around for a while. And if we just layer
on more efficient homes

with simple technologies
and the current state

of the shelf of things like
heat pumps, induction cooking, we're going to get homes that
are efficient but also provide

really good services. Generally, homeowners don't care
a lot about all these things--

decarbonization and all. But they really do care a lot
about comfort and well-being

in a home. So when we have a new stove-- if the induction stove
provides better service, that's

what's going to make
people happy and feel like, OK, this is the right thing. I think what we're going
to find with new heat pump

air conditioners is that
they provide better service. With the controls,
they can provide better

heating and cooling. It's more precise. It delivers it at the
time when they want it.

And then it's done
in a way that's more reliable because they have
just single piece of equipment.

They're not owning a
furnace and air conditioner and all this other
stuff that they have to maintain along with that.

So, yeah, I do think
that this all electric is going to be the
way things move.

And the hybrid house,
the combined fuel is going to be solely something
that's not interesting.

And part of what will drive it
and what I was trying to say is the cost of gas will get
more and more expensive.

So it's going to be less and
less attractive to people to have the hybrid house.

ANNETTE CRUZ: Yeah,
that makes sense. Everything is already
very expensive. So cutting costs on
some gas would be nice.

So next question,
how will society handle risk of relying
on one energy source,

like electricity? For example, in the
future, if outages happen at the
transmission level,

only those with
backup energy storage can have power availability. But on the worst
days, such as when

there are several
days of rain, this could be a risk for even
those who have solar battery.

Do you see hydrogen
having more role? PETER RUMSEY: Yeah.

So there's a lot there as
far as reliability, the grid,

and those kind of things. I think that the reliability
question of electricity-- and I live in California.

We're very familiar
with power outages because we've had these-- we didn't have them this year
because the fire season was

basically nonexistent because
we had good rain last year and snow. But the subsequent years, we
had for several years fires.

And the electric
company would turn off the power grid in
certain areas to avoid

those wires coming
in contact with trees and starting new fires.

So there are some questions
about the grid and reliability.

So the thing to understand
about gas appliances is that, for safety reasons, all of
the modern gas appliances--

not the old ones
but the new ones-- require electricity to operate.

We're not going to--
a gas furnace doesn't work without electricity.

Gas stoves, the newer ones that
are like 15 years and less,

require electricity. They have interlocks
so that you can't use the gas when the
electricity is not available.
So gas is also vulnerable.

This vulnerability
can be offset-- the electric vulnerability
with storage as the questioner

mentioned. And that storage
will be available not only at the utility level
but also in a distributed way.

So I think we're going to
see more and more storage. And then solar distributed--
and another reason why distributed solar
is a good thing.

So I think that
there's ways that we can make the electric
grid more reliable.

And that's fairly obvious. As far as hydrogen is concerned,
we will see a lot of hydrogen

in the future. There's no doubt
that hydrogen will be critical in
industrial processes.

There's a lot of industrial
processes that just need heat. And we can't get exactly what
we need with electricity.

And it will be more affordable
to do with hydrogen that's generated with renewable power. So a wide variety
of technologies

are being investigated
and industrial processes where hydrogen
becomes the key thing.

There's a lot of discussion
about using hydrogen in long distance. Trucking, for example,
is another area.

And there is discussion about
using hydrogen in homes. And there's been different
research projects on that

and tests of that. A lot of people are
saying that that's going to be a tough
sell in homes as

compared to electricity. We can't use existing gas
pipes with 100% hydrogen.

You can use 10% hydrogen.
But if you get above that, the hydrogen starts to decay.

Existing piping that
we use the steel pipes and the
different PVC pipes that we use for gas
don't work with hydrogen.

You have to have a
new pipe material. So putting in a new
hydrogen infrastructure

is probably going to
be more-- in most areas for homes is going to be
more expensive than just
electrifying. So hydrogen is part of our-- I'm sorry, hold on.

Hydrogen is part of our future. But the jury is out on how
big of a role it will play.

Yeah. ANNETTE CRUZ: OK, thank you. We have time for just
about one last question.

So I will go with
the next one, which is I am curious to know what
the role of structural engineers

is in the road to building
decarbonization and net zero. PETER RUMSEY: Well, I
think structural engineers

are critical on the embodied
carbon side of things. The structural
system and buildings

is the number one thing
for embodied carbon. So steel and cement--

that's eventually concrete--
those two things are-- depends on the building
type and everything.

But they can make up 75%
of the embodied carbon.

So in this discussion
about decarbonization, structural engineers are
becoming front and center.

Now, if we take a building
where it's efficient, it's electrified, it's
connected to renewable

energy, that's pretty easy to
do in a lot of areas in the US today. It's not a hard thing.

But what's left is
the embodied carbon. So there's lots of
buildings that I'm working on that they're
like, well, thank you, Peter.

Now we've got a problem
with the embodied carbon. It was always a problem. But now it's a bigger percent
of the carbon footprint

of the building. And so structural engineers are
becoming a very important part of that discussion. So I'd urge you to start digging
in and looking at alternatives

to steel and concrete
structures, mass timber and such. But then within the steel
and cement categories,

there's a wide
variety of options that are lower carbon and
starting to learn about those.

And some of those have
already been available and are widely used, things like
fly ash and cement and such.

So, yeah. ANNETTE CRUZ: Great. All right, well,
Peter, thanks again for this interesting and
insightful conversation

and for answering all of the
questions that we had time for. To everyone in the
audience with us

live today, thank you
for all your questions and participation as well. I want to remind you that
today's session was recorded.

And a link to this will be
made available to all of you within a week. So look forward to that
email in your inbox.

And have a great
rest of your day. Hope you all enjoyed
our session today. Thank you.
PETER RUMSEY: Thank you.
